title: Fish (Still Life)

thumbnail.alt_text: Still-life painting, fish, open oysters, eel, lemon on tablecloth.

description: Although still-life ensembles were an important element in many of the major paintings of the avant-garde artist Édouard Manet, his most sustained interest in the genre itself was from 1864 to 1865, when Fish was painted. Manet’s focus on still lifes coincided with the gradual reacceptance of the genre during the nineteenth century, due in part to the growth of the middle class, whose tastes ran to intimate, moderately priced works. This painting, like many of Manet’s still-life compositions, recalls seventeenth-century Dutch models. The directness of execution, bold brushwork, and immediacy of vision displayed in the canvas, however, suggest why the public found Manet’s work so unorthodox and confrontational. While Fish is indeed an image of “dead nature” (nature morte is the French term for still life), there is nothing still about the work: the produce seems fresh and the handling of paint vigorous. Further enliven-ing the composition is the placement of the carp, which offsets the strong diagonal of the other elements. Manet never submitted his still lifes to the official French Salon but rather sold them through the burgeoning network of art galleries in Paris and gave them to friends.
credit_line: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Larned Coburn Memorial Collection

Sweet, “An Important Stiff Life by Édouard Manet,” Art Institute Bulletin 38 (1944), pp. 35–37 (ill.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Masterpiece of the Month: Notes and Bibliography, (February 1944), pp. 82, 83. Paris, Exposition Internationale Universelle, Exposition Centennale de l’Art Français, 1880–1889, 1900, cat. 31.

Paris, Manzi, Joyant et Cie, Exposition d’art moderne, 1912, cat. 27.

New York, M. Knoedler & Co., Loan Exhibition of Old Masters, Nov. 29-Dec. 11, 1920, cat. 9.

New York, Brooklyn Museum of Art, The Triumph of Realism, 1967, cat. 5; Richmond, VA, Museum of Fine Arts, Dec. 11, 1967–Jan. 14, 1968; San Francisco, Feb. 17–Mar. 31, 1968, cat. 5.

provenance_text: The artist; possibly sold to Basset, Paris, 1867 [this and the following per emails from Juliet Wilson-Bareau to the Art Institute of Chicago, November 11, 2016 and April 24, 2017; copies in curatorial object file]; sold to Durand-Ruel, Paris, April 1872, for 250 francs [per Durand-Ruel, Paris, stock book for 1868–73 (no. 1228); copy of reference in curatorial object file]; possibly sold to Jean-Baptiste Faure (d. 1914), Paris, November 16, 1874, for 1,500 francs. Félix Gérard, Paris, by 1884 [lent to Paris, 1884, cat. 31]. Galerie Manzi-Joyant, Paris, by 1900 [Paris, 1900, cat. 449, p. 210]. John W. Simpson (d. 1920), New York, by November 22, 1913 [Simpson placed the picture on deposit at Durand-Ruel, New York (deposit no. 7731) on that day until December 23, 1913]; by descent to Mrs. John W. Simpson (née Kate Seney), New York, 1920; Knoedler and Co., New York, April 18, 1942 [M. Knoedler and Co., New York, Commission Book 3, Getty Research Institute Research Library, Los Angeles]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, July 1942.
